items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely tomorrow morning between 12am and 2am Wednesday 8th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to approaching spring tides. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level tonight at Harwich of 2.53mAODN at 1am on Wednesday 8th October which is 0.28m above tide tables, wind force 3, Westerly. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Wednesday 8th October.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message:
High tide levels and large waves may lead to flooding tomorrow morning, Wednesday 08/10/2025. Flooding of roads, low lying land, and exposed areas of the coast is possible. 

Flooding is possible between 04:00AM and 06:00AM tomorrow, and again on Thursday morning 09/10/2025. Areas most at risk include exposed areas of the coast particularly around Whitby, and The North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including Sandsend and the tidal River Esk. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths, and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. We are currently in a period of high tides so this alert may be re-issued if necessary. 

This message will be updated by 08:00AM on 08/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely tomorrow morning between 12am and 2am Wednesday 8th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to approaching spring tides. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level tonight at Harwich of 2.53mAODN at 1am on Wednesday 8th October which is 0.28m above tide tables, wind force 3, Westerly. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Wednesday 8th October.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.72 mAOD at 04:00 on 08/10/25 and 4.63mAOD at 16:00 on 08/10/25.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 17 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 08/10/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Higher than normal spring tides are forecast over the coming days. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
The first forecast high-water is 8:15 PM on 07/10/25 with a level of 7.61 mAOD and a Force 4 Westerly wind. The second forecast high-water is 8:45 AM on 08/10/25 with a level of 7.48 mAOD and a Force 3 Northerly wind. Times are local and refer to the high-water time at Avonmouth, mAOD is height above average sea level. Conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. 
Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.
Further flooding is possible at high-water until Thursday evening due to higher than normal tides. We are closely monitoring the situation and will be closing flood gates at Pill.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads where conditions may be hazardous.
This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 08/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings. High water at Ilfracombe on Tuesday evening is at 19:00, times of high water will vary along the coast.

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and update on Wednesday
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Tuesday evening is 5.07 mAOD.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
High tides are expected to reach the flood alert threshold overnight which may lead to flooding between 00:45 AM and 02:15 AM on 08/10/2025. The impacted locations are:

Fiddlers Ferry, peaking around 01:15 AM,

Eastford Road, peaking around 01:30 AM,

Arpley Bridge, peaking around 01:45 AM.

It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. 

The lunchtime tide tomorrow, 08/10/2025 will not reach flood alert, but the overnight tide on 09/10/2025 will pass the flood alert threshold.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 08/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message:
High tides are expected until the 10/10/25
 
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
The overnight tide at 12:15 AM on 08/10/25 will reach flood alert, with Arnside reaching 6.011M and Sandside reaching 6.113M. The lunchtime tide at 12:45 PM Wednesday 08/10/25 will peak at 5.753M which is above the flood alert level. The subsequent tide on 09/10/25 at 1:00 AM will also reach the flood alert level. Tides may be high 2 hours either side of these timings.
Areas that may be effected are the Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale.
 
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
 
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 09/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
High tides this evening may lead to flooding, with the high tide expected at 11:00PM. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Flooding is possible Tuesday evening for Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods. 
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
We do not expect to see impacts from the high tide tomorrow lunchtime, on Wednesday 08/10/2025, but it will meet the threshold at 23:45 tomorrow evening. 
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 08/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Heysham to Cockerham
items.message:
High tides overnight may lead to flooding.
Flooding is possible around the high tide from 11:00 PM on 07/10/2025.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Sandylands, Middleton, Sunderland, Bank Houses, Hillam, Sand Side and Cockerham Moss at 11:00 PM on 07/10/2025. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
We do not expect flooding from the high tide tomorrow lunch time, although the high tide threshold will be met at 23:45 tomorrow evening. 
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 08/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 6:30am and 8:30am tomorrow morning, Wednesday 8th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.72 mAODN at 7:30am, on Wednesday 8th October, which is 0.14m above tide tables, wind Force 4, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Wednesday 8th October, or if the situation changes.

The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.72 mAODN at 7:30am, on Wednesday 8th October, which is 0.14m above tide tables, wind Force 4, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. items.description: Tyne estuary

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
High spring tides tomorrow morning, 08/10/2025, may lead to flooding. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected. Flooding is possible around the high tide from 4:00 AM on 08/10/2025. Areas most at risk include low lying areas around Newcastle Swing Bridge.
High spring tides are forecast to over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying roads and footpaths. This message will be updated by this 9:00AM on 08/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely tomorrow between 12am and 2am Wednesday 8th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to approaching spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level tonight at Clacton of 2.99mAODN at 1am on Wednesday 8th October which is 0.19m above tide tables, wind force 3, Westerly. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Wednesday 8th October.

items.description: Coast from Heacham to north of King's Lynn in Norfolk
items.message: The forecast weather conditions during spring tides mean that high tides are expected between 06:30am and 08:30am on Wednesday 08 October 2025. Areas most at risk are Heacham, Snettisham, Ingoldisthorpe, Dersingham and Wolferton. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of 4.80mAODN at 07:30am, on Wednesday 08 October 2025, which is 0.13m above tide tables, wind Force 4, north-westerly. (mAODN is the height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The following tide on Wednesday 08 October 2025 at 19:00pm is not currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10:00am on Wednesday 08 October 2025.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message:
The forecast weather conditions during spring tides, means that high tides are expected between 06:30am and 08:30am, Wednesday 08 October 2025. 

Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront. Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. 

The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of 4.80mAODN at 07:30am, on Wednesday 08 October 2025, which is 0.13m above tide tables, wind Force 4, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  

The following tide on Wednesday 08 October 2025 at 19:00pm is not currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate.  

We will update this message by 10:00am Wednesday 08 October 2025.

The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of 4.80mAODN at 07:30am, on Wednesday 08 October 2025, which is 0.13m above tide tables, wind Force 4, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). 

The following tide on Wednesday 08 October 2025 at 19:00pm is not currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. 

Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. 

We will update this message by 10:00am Wednesday 08 October 2025.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message: A flood alert has been issued due to a period of high tides. Tides will be at their highest around 20:15 this evening 07/10/25 and between 08:30 and 08:45 on Wednesday 08/10/25. Flooding to roads and low-lying land adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow is expected at the time of high tides, however conditions may apply a few hours either side of the high tides. Predicted peaks at Newport 7.1m to 7.3m and Avonmouth 7.5m to 7.7m around 20:15 this evening Tuesday 07/10/25. Wednesday morning tide peaks Newport 6.9m to 7.2m and Avonmouth 7.4m to 7.6m. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 11:00 on 08/10/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank of the Humber estuary at Hessle Haven
items.message:
High tide levels and large waves are expected to lead to flooding tomorrow morning, Wednesday 08/10/2025. Flooding is possible between 07:00AM and 08:00AM tomorrow, and again on Thursday morning 09/10/2025. 

Flooding is expected to affect areas around Hessle foreshore including Hessle Haven. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Consider enacting your flood plan. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message by 09:00AM on 08/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

Creeksea Ferry Road onto Wallasea Island may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level tonight at Clacton of 2.99mAODN at 1am on Wednesday 8th October which is 0.19m above tide tables, wind force 3, Westerly. items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
High spring tides this evening may lead to flooding.

Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.

Highest tide level is expected to be at the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point, including Porlock Weir, at 7:45 PM on 07/10/2025. Flooding is possible an hour and a half either side of this time.

Further flood alerts may be issued due to higher than normal tides, but flooding is not expected tomorrow morning.
 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

The detailed tidal forecast, for those who use it, is for a peak level at Hinkley Point of 6.52 mAODN at 7:45 PM on 07/10/2025, with Westerly force 3 winds, gusting Force 4. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)

This message will be updated by 1:00 PM on 08/10/2025, or as the situation changes.
